content: The Nurse Training and Retention Act of 2007 may be cited as the official title. Key findings are outlined in the Act. The Nurse Training and Retention Act of 2007 highlights the growing shortage of nurses in the healthcare system. By 2020, there is projected to be a shortage of 1,016,900 nurses nationally. To address this issue, healthcare workers should have access to education and training opportunities. With proper support, current healthcare workers and bedside nurses can help alleviate the shortage. Healthcare workers and bedside nurses can address the nursing shortage and provide quality care as the American population ages. Establishment of grant program. The purpose of this section is to authorize grants to address the projected shortage of nurses, increase nurse education capacity, and provide training programs for healthcare workers. The Secretary of Labor will establish a partnership grant program to award grants to eligible healthcare entities for nurse education and career advancement programs. Eligible entities include healthcare organizations jointly administered by healthcare employers and labor unions. The partnership grant program awards grants to healthcare entities for nurse education and career advancement programs. Eligible entities include those jointly administered by healthcare providers or facilities and organizations representing direct care healthcare workers or staff nurses with input on leadership. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a healthcare employer must participate in a State training partnership program that includes equal participation from industry, labor organizations, and other relevant entities. The employer must also submit an application to the Secretary with required information. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a healthcare employer must demonstrate an established program to retain nurses, provide competitive wages and benefits, and support nursing career ladder programs through paid leave and health coverage for incumbent healthcare workers. Contributions to a joint labor-management program are also required. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a healthcare employer must demonstrate an established program to retain nurses, provide competitive wages and benefits, and support nursing career ladder programs through paid leave and health coverage for incumbent healthcare workers. Contributions to a joint labor-management training fund, paid release time for staff nurses to pursue further education, and tuition assistance managed by a joint labor-management training fund are also required. The Secretary may only grant funds if the applicant agrees to provide non-Federal contributions equal to at least $1 for every $1 of Federal funds. Contributions can be in cash, in-kind, or through paid release time for incumbent worker students. Non-Federal contributions required for programs under this section can be in cash or in kind, excluding federal government assistance. Collaboration with accredited schools of nursing is mandatory for entities overseeing these programs. Activities funded by grants under this section include education and training programs to establish nursing career ladders for healthcare workers to become nurses, such as Certified Nurse Assistants, Licensed Practical Nurses, Licensed Vocational Nurses, and Registered Nurses. Programs may include English as a second language education, GED education, pre-college counseling, college preparation classes, and entry support. Providing tuition assistance for nursing students in community colleges, universities, and accredited nursing schools. Support includes tutoring, counseling, and preparation for licensure tests. Orientation and mentorship programs for newly graduated nurses to aid in their transition to bedside nursing. Stipends for release time are also offered. Programs are in place to assist nurses in obtaining advanced degrees and completing specialty training. Incentives are provided for nurses to take on nurse faculty positions. This includes funding for nurses to return to school and incentives for bedside nurses with advanced degrees to teach in nursing programs. Stipends for release time and continued healthcare coverage are also offered. Bedside nurses can obtain leave to teach in nursing programs without losing salary or benefits. Collaboration with accredited schools for innovative nursing programs is preferred for grants. The curr_chunk discusses criteria for grants to improve nurse retention, diversity of new nurse graduates, quality of nursing education, and upgrading healthcare workers to become nurses. Evaluation of grant activities is required. The curr_chunk outlines outcomes of grant activities to improve nursing education and workforce, including increased enrollment in nursing programs, improved graduation and licensure rates, nurse retention, staff nurse numbers, advanced degrees, nurse faculty, and patient quality measures. The curr_chunk discusses the authorization of appropriations for the grant program to improve nursing education and workforce outcomes.
